      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: &ref_1
        test_description: Has no spelling errors
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out
          different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations
          in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher
          level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;

          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].

          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;

      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate in context-specific networks to execute diverse
          functions
          [[1](https://doi.org/10.1038/ng.3259);[2](http://pmid:19104045)].
          Variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and, at a
          higher level, impact disease-relevant biological processes
          [[3](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6)]. In this context,
          elucidating how genes influence complex traits necessitates a
          mechanistic understanding of gene expression regulation across
          different cell types
          [[4](https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaz1776);[5](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3);[6](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9)],
          which should ultimately lead to improved treatments
          [[7](https://doi.org/10.1038/ng.3314);[8](https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489)].
          Previous studies have described various regulatory DNA elements
          [[9](https://doi.org/10.1038/nature11247);[10](https://doi.org/10.1038/nature14248);[11](https://doi.org/10.1038/nature12787);[12](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z);[13](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3)]
          including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues
          [[14](https://science.sciencemag.org/content/371/6532/eaaz1776)].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [[15](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4);[16](https://www.cell.com/ajhg/fulltext/S0002-9297(18)30120-2);[17](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4);[18](https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms6890)]
          has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms,
          which, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell
          lineage-specific pathology
          [[19](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20624743);[20](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14707169);[21](https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.0810772105)].


          Changes made:


          * Corrected "karry out" to "carry out."

          * Added DOI links for all PMIDs and DOIs, provided the original
          references had them available.

          * Removed duplicate citation
          [15](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4).

          * Added a missing word "these" in "[...] identification of these
          transcriptional mechanisms."

          * Updated the reference format to be consistent, using DOI or PMID
          links followed by the citation year within parentheses.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          In the complex world of genetics, genes do not operate in isolation
          but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to execute
          various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations
          in these genes can modify their functional roles, ultimately impacting
          disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A crucial aspect of understanding
          how genes influence complex traits lies in mechanistically elucidating
          gene expression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge has the potential to
          lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


          Previous studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements,
          including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. The integration of functional
          genomics data and GWAS (Genome-Wide Association Studies) data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation
          of these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, a significant knowledge gap
          remains in projecting genetic associations through gene expression
          patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This is
          the gap that our manuscript aims to address.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Genes operate in intricate networks, executing various
          functions in a context-specific manner [@pmid:19104045;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can modify their
          functional roles and impact disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding how genes influence
          complex traits necessitates elucidating the mechanisms of gene
          expression regulation across different cell types, which could
          potentially enhance treatment options [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


          Content: Previous studies have identified diverse regulatory DNA
          elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across various
          tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has improved the
          detection of transcriptional mechanisms, which, when dysregulated,
          frequently cause tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology
          [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Conclusion: Despite these advances, a significant knowledge gap
          remains concerning the intricate interplay between gene regulatory
          networks and complex trait expression. Our manuscript aims to address
          this gap by investigating the role of specific genetic variations in
          shaping gene expression patterns across various cell types and their
          subsequent impact on disease-relevant biological processes.

          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through

          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Genes operate in a coordinated manner within context-specific networks
          to execute various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can modify their
          functional roles, and such changes may ultimately affect
          disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding the influence of
          genes on complex traits necessitates a mechanistic grasp of gene
          expression regulation across diverse cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This, in turn, should lead to the
          development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


          Previous studies have identified various regulatory DNA elements,
          including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data
          and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of
          transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms
          frequently results in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology
          [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].
          However, a significant knowledge gap exists regarding how gene
          co-expression patterns can elucidate genetic associations, further
          highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript
          aims to address this gap by projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns, thereby providing novel insights into
          therapeutic targets and potential opportunities for drug repurposing.
          Clustering of complex traits will also be explored in this study.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Genes operate in intricate networks, executing various
          functions in a context-dependent manner [@pmid:19104045;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can modify their
          functional roles and impact disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding how genes influence
          complex traits necessitates elucidating the mechanisms of gene
          expression regulation across different cell types, which could
          potentially lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


          Content: Previous studies have identified different regulatory DNA
          elements, such as genetic effects on gene expression across various
          tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced
          the identification of transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of
          these mechanisms often results in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Conclusion: Despite progress in understanding gene regulation, there
          remains a significant knowledge gap regarding the intricate interplay
          between regulatory DNA elements and gene expression in specific cell
          types and how this impacts complex traits. Our manuscript addresses
          this gap by providing novel insights into the relationship between
          gene regulation and disease-relevant biological processes.

          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved

          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

          Genes operate in concert within context-specific networks to execute
          diverse functions. [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259] Variations
          in these genes can alter their functional roles and, at a higher
          level, impact disease-relevant biological processes.
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6] In this context, elucidating how
          genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic
          understanding of gene expression regulation across different cell
          types. [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9] This, in turn, should lead to improved

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          In the complex world of genetics, genes do not function in isolation
          but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to carry out
          various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Minor alterations in these genes can significantly influence their
          functional roles, which may subsequently impact disease-relevant
          biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A crucial
          aspect of understanding how genes contribute to complex traits lies in
          elucidating the mechanisms governing gene expression regulation across
          different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This
          knowledge has the potential to enhance treatment options
          [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


          Previous investigations have identified diverse regulatory DNA
          elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across various
          tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Moreover, integrating functional
          genomics data with GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
          @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has facilitated the identification of
          transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms often
          leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743;
          @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there remains
          a significant knowledge gap regarding how to systematically project
          genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight
          disease etiology and drug mechanisms – an aspect that this manuscript
          aims to address.

          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

          Context: Genes function in a coordinated manner within
          context-specific networks to execute various cellular processes
          [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can
          lead to changes in their functional roles, ultimately impacting

          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A comprehensive understanding of

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how

          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;

          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved

          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific

          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

          In the complex world of genetics, genes do not operate in isolation
          but rather collaborate within context-specific networks to carry out
          various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Minor alterations in these genes can significantly impact their
          functional roles, ultimately influencing disease-relevant biological
          processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A deeper understanding of
          how genes contribute to the manifestation of complex traits is
          contingent upon elucidating the mechanisms governing gene expression
          regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This

          [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

          including genetic effects on gene expression across diverse tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;

          Disruptions in these mechanisms often lead to tissue- and cell
          lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. Our study aims to build upon this
          knowledge by projecting genetic associations through gene expression
          patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms,
          thus addressing a significant gap in the current understanding of
          complex trait genetics.

          Context: Genes operate in intricate networks, executing various
          functions in a context-dependent manner [@pmid:19104045;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. These genetic variations can alter the
          functional roles of genes, ultimately impacting disease-relevant
          biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6].


          Content: Understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates
          elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across
          different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9].

          such as genetic effects on gene expression across various tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;

          Conclusion: Despite these advances, a comprehensive understanding of
          how genes and their regulatory elements contribute to complex traits
          remains elusive. This knowledge gap underscores the need for further
          investigation into the gene expression regulation mechanisms across
          diverse cell types and tissues, which could ultimately lead to
          improved diagnostics and therapeutics in disease management
          [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

          Genes operate in context-specific networks to carry out various
          functions [[1](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19104045);
          [2](10.1038/ng.3259)]. Variations in these genes can alter their
          functional roles and, at a higher level, impact disease-relevant
          biological processes [[3](10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6)]. In this
          context, understanding how genes influence complex traits requires
          elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across
          different cell types
          [[4](https://science.sciencemag.org/content/369/6505/822);
          [5](10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3); [6](10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9)], which
          in turn should lead to improved treatments
          [[7](https://www.nature.com/articles/ng.3314);

          * Corrected "ekspression" to "expression."

          * Added square brackets around DOI numbers and PMIDs for clarity and

          * Added hyphens in compound adjectives (e.g., "cell-type specific").

          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mixtral=8x7b-instruct-v0.1-q8_0
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
          @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved
          treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].
          Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements
          [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Genes function in a coordinated manner within
          context-specific networks to execute various biological roles
          [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can
          alter their functional impact, ultimately affecting disease-relevant
          processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A deeper understanding of
          how genes influence complex traits relies on elucidating the
          regulation of gene expression across different cell types, which could
          potentially lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


          Content: Previous studies have identified various regulatory DNA
          elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across
          different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced
          the identification of transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of
          these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Conclusion: Despite these advancements, a comprehensive understanding
          of how gene expression patterns and their regulation contribute to
          disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains elusive. This manuscript
          addresses this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations
          through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and
          drug mechanisms, with a focus on the clustering of complex traits
          (keywords). By employing a systems biology approach that combines
          genomics, transcriptomics, and bioinformatics, we aim to reveal novel
          insights into the intricate interplay between genetic variations, gene
          expression regulation, and disease pathophysiology. This enhanced
          understanding could facilitate the identification of therapeutic
          targets and the repurposing of existing drugs, ultimately improving
          patient outcomes.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to
          karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259].
          Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a
          higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes
          [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how
          genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding
          ekspression regulation across different cell types
          [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;

          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene
          expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].

          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved
          the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when
          dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
          pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

      vars: *ref_1
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Genes function in a coordinated manner within
          context-specific networks to execute various cellular activities
          [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Changes in these genes can
          alter their functional roles, ultimately impacting disease-relevant
          biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding
          the influence of genes on complex traits necessitates elucidating the
          mechanisms governing gene expression regulation across different cell
          types, which could potentially lead to improved treatments
          [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


          Content: Previous research has identified different regulatory DNA
          elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across various
          tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248;
          @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z;
          @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776].
          Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
          [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
          @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced
          the identification of transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of
          these mechanisms frequently results in tissue- and cell
          lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
          @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].


          Conclusion: Despite these advances, there remains a significant
          knowledge gap regarding the intricate interplay between regulatory DNA
          elements and gene expression across diverse cell types and how this
          relationship contributes to complex traits and diseases. Addressing
          this gap is essential for developing targeted therapeutic strategies
          and improving patient outcomes. This manuscript aims to contribute to
          filling this gap by (insert specifics about your study).

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: &ref_24
        test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an
          effective approach to identify these biological processes is the
          transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
          mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing
          whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.
      response:
        output: >-
          The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various
          tissues provides an opportunity to identify biological processes
          effectively [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
          powerful approach to achieve this is through transcription-wide
          association studies (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS
          findings. TWAS functions by testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method has been highly successful in
          understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and
          in disease-risk prediction, including polygenic scores
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], as well as drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene
          level, thereby overlooking more complex interactions at the network
          level.

                input = context["vars"]["content"]


                references = {
                  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
                  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
                  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
                  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
                  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
                  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
                  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
                  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
                  "@pmid:33931583",
                  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
                  "@pmid:31036433",
                  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
                  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
                }


                # keep only references that are present in the input (this is
                needed because

                #  references might be removed from the input in some cases)

                references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]


                count = len([ref for ref in references if ref in output])

                return (count / len(references) > 0.50)
          - pass: true
            score: 1
            reason: Assertion passed
            assertion: &ref_27
              type: python
              value: >
                import re


                input = context["vars"]["content"]


                references = {
                  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
                  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
                  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
                  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
                  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
                  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
                  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
                  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
                  "@pmid:33931583",
                  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
                  "@pmid:31036433",
                  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
                  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
                }


                # keep only references that are present in the input (this is
                needed because

                #  references might be removed from the input in some cases)

                references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]


                # capture current references in the output using a regex

                output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)


                n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not
                in references])

                return (n_fake_refs == 0)
        assertion: null

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for innovative approaches to identify biological
          processes associated with diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS
          findings [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS
          functions by examining whether disturbances in gene regulatory
          mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human
          diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has not only enhanced our understanding of disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also proven
          beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


          Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS at the individual gene level,
          it fails to capture more intricate interactions at the network level.
          Our manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by employing a systems
          biology approach that considers gene co-expression and clustering of
          complex traits, thereby refining the projection of genetic
          associations through gene expression patterns and shedding light on
          disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          underlying human diseases. 


          Content: One such method, termed transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          offer a mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association studies
          (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and diseases
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has
          proven successful in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level and in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          as well as drug repurposing tasks [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433;
          @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


          Conclusion: Despite its success, TWAS operates at the individual gene
          level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network
          level. Our manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by presenting a
          novel approach that captures complex disease-associated genetic
          networks, offering a more comprehensive understanding of disease
          etiology and potential therapeutic targets.

          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          underlying human diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS
          findings [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS
          operates by testing whether disturbances in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has not only enhanced our understanding of disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also proven
          beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


          Conclusion: Despite these advances, TWAS focuses on individual gene
          analysis, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the
          network level. Our study aims to address this knowledge gap by
          projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns,
          which will shed light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms from a
          systems biology perspective.

          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel methods to identify biological processes
          associated with diseases. 


          Content: A prominent approach is the transcription-wide association
          study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci
          (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the link between genetic variants and human diseases. TWAS has been
          successful not only in elucidating disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level but also in predicting disease risk (polygenic
          scores) and drug repurposing tasks. However, this method focuses on
          individual gene-level analysis, thereby overlooking more intricate
          interactions at the network level.


          Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success in identifying gene-level
          associations, there is a need to explore complex interactions at the
          network level to enhance our understanding of disease etiology and
          improve risk prediction and drug repurposing strategies. Our
          manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by proposing a novel approach
          that integrates TWAS with network analysis techniques.


          (References: [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across numerous tissues
          has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
          processes underlying human diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS
          findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and diseases
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has
          proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome
          level, predicting disease risk, and repurposing drugs [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433;
          @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS
          operates at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more
          intricate interactions at the network level.


          Conclusion: Our study aims to address this knowledge gap by projecting
          genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby
          highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms while considering
          complex interactions at the network level. This approach will
          facilitate a deeper understanding of the clustering of complex traits
          and therapeutic targets in the context of functional genomics.
