      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          underlying human diseases. One such method, the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), has garnered significant attention due to
          its ability to offer mechanistic insights into GWAS findings by
          integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data.


          Content: TWAS functions by testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has been highly successful in
          understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and
          has also contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


          Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS in identifying individual gene
          contributions to disease, it does not capture more complex
          interactions at the network level. Bridging this knowledge gap
          requires the development and implementation of methods that can model
          these intricate relationships, thereby advancing our understanding of
          disease pathophysiology and informing novel therapeutic strategies.

          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.

          The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various
          tissues provides an opportunity to investigate biological processes
          systematically [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A powerful approach to achieve this
          is through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which
          amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
          mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. TWAS focuses on examining
          whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          relationship between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method
          has proven highly successful in elucidating disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] and has also contributed to disease-risk prediction
          (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug
          repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the
          individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions
          at the network level.

          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          associated with diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative

          findings [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;

          level interactions limits its ability to capture more intricate
          network-level interactions. Our manuscript addresses this knowledge
          gap by employing a systems biology approach that considers complex
          interactions among genes, thereby providing a deeper understanding of
          disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)

          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the

          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes. 


          Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS
          findings by testing whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the link between genetic variants and human diseases. This
          approach has achieved considerable success in elucidating disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level and has been instrumental in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks.
          However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby
          overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.


          Conclusion: Despite its accomplishments, TWAS's limitation in
          capturing complex interactions at the network level underscores the
          need for further research to enhance our understanding of disease
          etiology and improve risk prediction and drug repurposing strategies.
          Our manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by proposing an innovative
          approach that integrates TWAS with network-level analysis, thereby
          potentially unlocking new insights into disease mechanisms and
          facilitating more effective therapeutic interventions.
          ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          The increasing accessibility of gene expression data across various
          tissues provides an opportunity to identify biological processes
          effectively [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
          promising approach to achieve this is through the use of
          transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which integrates
          expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic
          understanding of GWAS findings. TWAS functions by testing whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method
          has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] and has also proven beneficial in disease-risk
          prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and
          drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates
          at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate
          interactions at the network level.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_24
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          underlying human diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of
          genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS
          operates by testing whether disturbances in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has not only enhanced our understanding of disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also
          demonstrated success in disease-risk prediction, known as polygenic
          scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


          Conclusion: Despite TWAS's individual gene-level focus, which has
          proven beneficial in several aspects, it fails to capture more
          intricate network-level interactions. Our manuscript addresses this
          knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene
          expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms at a systems level.

          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS
          relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these

          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual
          gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
          network level.

          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          underlying human diseases. 


          Content: A notable method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which combines expression quantitative trait
          loci (eQTLs) data with GWAS findings to offer a mechanistic
          interpretation of genetic variants' role in disease etiology
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has
          achieved remarkable success in explaining disease transcriptome-level
          mechanisms [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433], disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. 


          Conclusion: Despite TWAS' individual gene level focus, which has
          proven successful in several applications, there remains a need to
          explore more complex interactions at the network level, highlighting
          an aspect of the knowledge gap this manuscript aims to address.

          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;

          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the

          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.

          Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) focus on determining
          whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          relationship between genetic variants and human diseases
          ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482]; @[doi:10.1038/ng.3506];
          @[doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889]; @[doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). These
          methods have been highly successful in elucidating disease etiology at
          the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583];
          @[doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]; @[pmid:31036433]) and have been
          applied to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]) and drug repurposing tasks
          ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). With the abundance of gene expression data
          across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838];
          @[doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6]; @[doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776];
          @[doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]), TWAS offers an effective approach
          to identify implicated biological processes by integrating expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby providing a mechanistic
          interpretation for GWAS findings. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the
          individual gene level, which may overlook more complex interactions at
          the network level.

        output: >-
          Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type of genetic
          investigation that aims to understand if alterations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms play a role in the relationship between genetic
          variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Such approaches have been successful in several
          aspects, including elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome
          level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk through polygenic scores
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundance of gene expression data across
          various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has made TWAS a valuable tool, as it
          combines expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
          mechanistic interpretation for findings from genome-wide association
          studies (GWAS). Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene
          level, which may overlook more intricate interactions occurring at the
          network level. This limitation underscores the necessity of exploring
          methods that can capture these complexities in genetic associations,
          an aspect addressed by our manuscript as we delve into the analysis of
          gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits.


          Context:

          Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a
          valuable tool to understand if alterations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms play a role in the relationship between genetic variants
          and human diseases, with successful applications in disease etiology,
          risk prediction, and drug repurposing tasks.


          Content:

          The abundance of gene expression data across various tissues has made
          TWAS an even more powerful approach by combining expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic
          interpretation for findings from genome-wide association studies
          (GWAS). However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may
          overlook more intricate interactions occurring at the network level.


          Conclusion:

          This limitation underscores the necessity of exploring methods that
          can capture these complexities in genetic associations, an aspect
          addressed by our manuscript as we delve into the analysis of gene
          co-expression and clustering of complex traits.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a powerful tool in
          genomics, designed to examine the role of perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms in the association between genetic variants and
          human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been successful in
          understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and
          have also been applied in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundance of gene expression data across
          various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has led to the use of TWAS as an
          effective method to identify implicated biological processes. This
          approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          provide a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide Association
          Studies (GWAS) findings. However, a limitation of TWAS is that it
          operates at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more
          intricate interactions at the network level.


          In summary, while TWAS has proven to be a valuable tool in genomics
          research, its focus on individual gene-level analysis may result in
          the overlook of complex interactions at the network level. Our study
          aims to address this knowledge gap by exploring methods that can
          capture these intricate interactions and provide a more comprehensive
          understanding of the relationship between genetic variants and human
          diseases.

          loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS
          findings. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby
          overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)

          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type of genetic
          analysis that aims to understand the relationship between genetic
          variants and human diseases by examining perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has been successful in
          elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and
          has been applied to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundance of gene expression data across
          various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has facilitated the use of TWAS,
          which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          offer a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association studies
          (GWAS) findings. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level,
          thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.
          Bridging this knowledge gap by exploring higher levels of genetic
          organization and their relationship to disease etiology is a key
          objective of our manuscript.


          In summary, TWAS has proven to be a valuable tool in understanding
          disease etiology, predicting disease risk, and repurposing drugs
          through the examination of gene regulatory mechanisms. The
          availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues has
          further enhanced the utility of TWAS. Nevertheless, the current focus
          on individual genes leaves a gap in comprehending more complex
          network-level interactions, which our manuscript aims to address by
          projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns and
          highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

          Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a powerful tool in
          genomics research, focusing on the impact of genetic variants on human
          diseases through alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has significantly advanced our understanding of disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and has been
          instrumental in disease-risk prediction, such as polygenic scores
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. With the abundance of gene expression data
          across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS, which incorporates expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, offers a valuable method to
          explain GWAS findings mechanistically at the individual gene level.
          Nevertheless, TWAS does not account for more intricate interactions at
          the network level, representing an area in need of further
          exploration.

          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) focus on determining
          whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms underlie the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases
          ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482]; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506];
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889]; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). This
          methodology has proven highly successful in elucidating disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583];
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]; @pmid:31036433]) and has further
          contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]) and drug repurposing efforts
          ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). With the abundance of gene expression data
          across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838];
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6]; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776];
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]), TWAS offers an effective approach
          to identify implicated biological processes by integrating expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby providing a mechanistic
          interpretation for GWAS findings. However, it is important to note
          that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook
          more intricate interactions at the network level.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type of genetic
          investigation that aims to determine if alterations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms play a role in the association between genetic variants and
          human diseases (Doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482, Doi:10.1038/ng.3506,
          Doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889, Doi:10.1038/ng.3367). These studies
          have been successful in elucidating disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level (Pmid:33931583, Doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225,
          Pmid:31036433) and have also been applied to disease-risk prediction
          (polygenic scores) (Doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w) and drug
          repurposing tasks (Doi:10.1038/nn.4618). The abundance of gene
          expression data across various tissues (Doi:10.1038/nbt.3838,
          Doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6, Doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776,
          Doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9) has facilitated the use of TWAS in
          identifying biological processes. This approach integrates expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic
          understanding of GWAS findings. However, one limitation of TWAS is
          that it operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook more
          intricate interactions at the network level.


          In this manuscript, we aim to address this knowledge gap by proposing
          a novel approach that projects genetic associations through gene
          expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms. Our method moves beyond the individual gene focus of TWAS
          to consider complex interactions at the network level, thus providing
          a more comprehensive understanding of the relationship between
          genetics and human diseases. By clustering complex traits and
          identifying therapeutic targets through functional genomics, our
          approach offers new possibilities for disease-risk prediction, drug
          repurposing, and the development of novel treatments.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a class of
          analytical methods that test whether disturbances in gene regulatory
          mechanisms underlie the association between genetic variants and human
          diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These
          approaches have been highly successful in several areas, including
          understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433],
          disease-risk prediction via polygenic scores
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundance of gene expression data across
          various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has led to the development of TWAS,
          which combines expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. Despite its
          utility, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby
          overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. This
          knowledge gap underscores the need for methods that can capture
          complex genetic interactions in human diseases, which is a key focus
          of our manuscript.

        output: >-
          Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a class of genetic
          analysis methods that aim to elucidate the relationship between
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms and the association
          between genetic variants and human diseases
          (Doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482, Doi:10.1038/ng.3506,
          Doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889, Doi:10.1038/ng.3367). These
          approaches have been successful in understanding disease etiology at
          the transcriptome level (PMID:33931583,
          Doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225, PMID:31036433) and have also been
          applied to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          (Doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w) and drug repurposing tasks
          (Doi:10.1038/nn.4618). With the availability of gene expression data
          across various tissues (Doi:10.1038/nbt.3838,
          Doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6, Doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776,
          Doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9), TWAS has emerged as an effective tool
          for identifying these biological processes by integrating expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic
          interpretation of GWAS findings. However, TWAS operates at the
          individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions
          occurring at the network level. This limitation highlights the need
          for further research into the clustering of complex traits and
          functional genomics to better understand genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns and their implications for disease etiology
          and drug mechanisms.

        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) focus on examining
          whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms underlie the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases
          ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482]; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506];
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889]; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). This
          methodology has been highly successful in elucidating disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583];
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]; @pmid:31036433]) and has proven
          beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]) and drug repurposing tasks
          ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). Given the abundance of gene expression data
          across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838];
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6]; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776];
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]), TWAS offers an effective approach
          to identify implicated biological processes by integrating expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby providing a mechanistic
          interpretation for GWAS findings. However, it is important to note
          that TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook
          more intricate interactions at the network level.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type of
          genetic study that has been widely used to understand disease etiology
          and predict disease risk [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w;
          @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. These studies integrate gene expression data
          with genetic variants to identify genes associated with diseases.


          Content: TWAS has been successful in identifying biological processes
          at the transcriptome level and in disease-risk prediction tasks
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433].
          With the availability of gene expression data across several tissues
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS
          has become an effective approach to provide a mechanistic
          interpretation for GWAS findings by integrating expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. However, current TWAS approaches
          mainly focus on individual gene level analysis and do not capture more
          complex interactions at the network level.


          Conclusion: This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by
          proposing a novel approach that projects genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms at the network level. By clustering complex traits
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433],
          our method aims to identify therapeutic targets and facilitate drug
          repurposing, thereby advancing the field of functional genomics and
          precision medicine.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
          successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
          transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene
          expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_42
      response:
        output: >-
          Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a powerful tool in
          genomics research, focusing on the relationship between genetic
          variants and human diseases through perturbations in gene regulatory
          mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These
          approaches have significantly contributed to understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and have been
          successful in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. With the abundance of gene expression data
          across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS, which integrates expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, offers a valuable approach for
          providing mechanistic insights into Genome-Wide Association Studies
          (GWAS) findings. Nevertheless, by focusing on individual genes, TWAS
          may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level. This
          knowledge gap concerning complex gene interactions drives the need for
          further investigation in this area.

          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

          The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various
          tissues provides an opportunity to identify biological processes
          effectively [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
          promising approach to achieve this is through transcription-wide
          association studies (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS
          findings. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level,
          thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.
          TWAS methodologies involve testing whether perturbations in gene
          regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants
          and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and such approaches have proven highly
          successful in several areas. They have enhanced our understanding of
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;

          disease-risk prediction via polygenic scores
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and facilitated drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          associated with diseases at the molecular level. 


          Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
          with GWAS findings to offer a mechanistic interpretation of these
          genetic associations [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. By testing whether alterations in
          gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants
          and human diseases, TWAS has proven successful in comprehending
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367] and has
          contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Nevertheless, TWAS primarily focuses on
          individual gene level analysis, overlooking more intricate
          interactions at the network level.


          Conclusion: Our manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by
          projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns,
          emphasizing not only single gene-based but also gene co-expression and
          clustering of complex traits [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. This comprehensive
          strategy will shed light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms,
          further advancing functional genomics and therapeutic target
          discovery.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          associated with human diseases. 


          Content: A notable method, transcription-wide association studies
          (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings by testing whether
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
          between genetic variants and diseases [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
          @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has proven successful in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has contributed to
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene level
          analysis, which may overlook more complex interactions at the network
          level.


          Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires the development of
          methods that can effectively capture and interpret the intricate
          interplay among genes within biological networks, thereby providing a
          comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and facilitating the
          discovery of novel therapeutic targets.

          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge

          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;

          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          associated with diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
          with GWAS findings to offer a mechanistic understanding of disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS operates at the individual gene
          level, focusing on perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms as
          mediators between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has not only enhanced our understanding of disease etiology
          but also contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS's reliance on individual
          gene-level analysis may overlook intricate interactions at the network
          level.


          Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap, our manuscript introduces a
          novel framework that projects genetic associations through gene
          expression patterns, capturing complex interactions at both the
          individual gene and network levels. This innovative approach, grounded
          in functional genomics and leveraging gene co-expression, offers
          enhanced insights into disease etiology, therapeutic targets, and drug
          mechanisms, thereby contributing to the clustering of complex traits.

          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for sophisticated bioinformatics approaches to identify
          biological processes associated with these data
          ["@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9"]. One
          such method is the Transcription-Wide Association Study (TWAS), which
          integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
          mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings.


          Content: TWAS functions at the individual gene level, thereby
          overlooking intricate interactions at the network level. This approach
          tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
          association between genetic variants and human diseases
          ["@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367"]. Such TWAS
          applications have achieved remarkable success in understanding disease
          etiology at the transcriptome level ["@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433"], as well as in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          ["@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w"] and drug repurposing tasks
          ["@doi:10.1038/nn.4618"].


          Conclusion: Despite these accomplishments, TWAS's reliance on
          individual gene-level analysis may preclude a comprehensive
          understanding of complex disease mechanisms driven by interactions at
          the network level. Bridging this knowledge gap requires the
          development and implementation of novel computational approaches
          capable of capturing higher-order genetic architectures underlying
          human diseases.

          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A
          powerful method for this purpose is the transcription-wide association
          study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci
          (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby
          overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. TWAS
          seeks to determine whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been remarkably successful not only in elucidating
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          predicting disease risk (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].
