        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          associated with diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS
          findings at an individual gene level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS has been instrumental in
          elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has proven
          beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level
          analysis, thereby overlooking intricate interactions at the network
          level.


          Conclusion: Our study aims to address this knowledge gap by employing
          a systems biology approach that clusters complex traits based on gene
          co-expression patterns [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. This strategy will
          enable the identification of therapeutic targets and facilitate drug
          repurposing, thereby advancing our understanding of disease etiology
          and mechanisms.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these
          approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding
          disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_59
      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes,
          offering valuable insights into disease etiology and potential
          therapeutic interventions. 


          Content: A prominent method in this field is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS) [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. By integrating expression
          quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS provides a mechanistic
          interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings at
          the individual gene level. This approach has been highly successful in
          understanding disease mechanisms at the transcriptome level
          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and
          has contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level
          associations and does not account for more intricate interactions at
          the network level.


          Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires the development of
          methods that can capture complex genetic interactions at the network
          level, thereby providing a more comprehensive understanding of disease
          etiology and potential therapeutic targets
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Our
          manuscript aims to address this need by presenting a novel approach
          that integrates TWAS with gene network analysis, thereby enhancing the
          interpretation and utility of GWAS findings.

          The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various
          tissues provides an opportunity to investigate biological processes on
          a transcription-wide scale [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A powerful approach to achieve this
          is through the use of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS),
          which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. Nevertheless, TWAS
          operates at an individual gene level, thereby overlooking more
          intricate interactions at the network level. Central to TWAS is the
          examination of whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
          mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
          approach has not only enhanced our understanding of disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also
          significantly contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic
          scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          underlying human diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association studies
          (TWAS), amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
          with GWAS findings to offer a mechanistic interpretation at the
          individual gene level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;

          [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and
          has contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level
          analysis, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the
          network level.


          Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap, our manuscript introduces a
          novel approach that projects genetic associations through gene
          expression patterns to uncover complex disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms, specifically addressing the limitations of TWAS by
          considering gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits within
          functional genomics. This advancement is expected to significantly
          impact therapeutic target identification and drug repurposing
          endeavors.

          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)

          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

      response:
        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes
          underlying human diseases. 


          Content: A prominent method in this regard is the transcription-wide
          association study (TWAS), which amalgamates expression quantitative
          trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS
          findings at the individual gene level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. By testing whether perturbations in
          gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
          variants and human diseases, TWAS has achieved remarkable success in
          comprehending disease etiology at the transcriptome level
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367;
          @pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433].
          This approach has also proven beneficial in disease-risk prediction,
          commonly known as polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w],
          and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS
          primarily focuses on individual gene-level associations, thereby
          overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.


          Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap, our manuscript introduces a
          novel method that projects genetic associations onto gene expression
          patterns to elucidate complex trait architectures and identify
          therapeutic targets by capitalizing on gene co-expression networks.
          This strategy not only enhances our understanding of disease etiology
          and drug mechanisms but also facilitates the clustering of complex
          traits, thereby providing a more comprehensive framework for genetic
          studies and functional genomics research.

          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across
          several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
          @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify
          these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study
          (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
          data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings.
          However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not
          capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on
          testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate
          the association between genetic variants and human diseases
          [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

        output: >-
          Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has
          paved the way for sophisticated analytical techniques to identify
          biological processes underlying human diseases. 


          Content: A prominent approach, transcription-wide association studies
          (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
          offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings by testing
          perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms at the individual gene
          level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
          @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. This
          method has been successful not only in understanding disease etiology
          at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
          disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
          [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
          [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual gene-level
          analysis, thereby overlooking more complex interactions at the network
          level.


          Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS in interpreting GWAS findings
          and its applications in disease risk prediction and drug repurposing,
          there is a need to address the knowledge gap concerning the detection
          of intricate interactions at the network level in gene regulatory
          mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
          @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This unmet
          need presents an opportunity for the current manuscript to contribute
          to the field by proposing novel methods or refining existing ones to
          capture these complexities in gene regulatory networks.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mixtral=8x7b-instruct-v0.1-q8_0
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: &ref_76
        test_description: has proper last paragraph structure
        title: >-
          Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
          highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
        keywords: >-
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
        content: >-
          Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a gene
          module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our method
          allows integrating different data modalities into the same
          representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
          perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.
      response:
        output: >-
          We introduce PhenoPLIER, a comprehensive method that offers an
          omnigenic view for genetic studies by considering gene modules. Our
          approach integrates various data modalities into a unified
          representation, facilitating joint analysis. We demonstrate that this
          module-based perspective can infer how groups of functionally related
          genes influence complex traits, identify shared and distinct
          transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict the impact of
          pharmacological perturbations on gene activity.


          PhenoPLIER represents gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses in a shared latent space. To achieve this,
          we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations from TWAS in
          PhenomeXcan and transcriptional profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000
          into a low-dimensional space, which is learned from publicly available
          gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples in
          recount2. We use a matrix factorization approach to define the latent
          representation, focusing on extracting gene modules with sparsity
          constraints and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge
          (e.g., pathways).


          When mapping gene-trait associations into this reduced expression
          space, we observe significant connections between diseases and gene
          modules expressed in relevant cell types. Examples include
          hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
          keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell
          types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders with different brain cell types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can
          identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or
          disease states.


          We validate our approach by comparing significant module-trait
          associations in the discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan) with those in the
          replication cohort (Electronic Medical Records and Genomics network
          phase III). Our results indicate that modules provide a more robust
          means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


          Additionally, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
          in HepG2 cells. We find that modules have stronger trait associations
          than individual genes, even when single genes involved in lipid
          metabolism do not reach genome-wide significance. Our module-based
          method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
          capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms related to the
          mechanism of action of drugs.


          Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
          associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving
          lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes acting
          together in specific cell types, enhancing robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations. This approach offers the potential
          to extract mechanistic insights from statistical associations,
          ultimately improving our understanding of complex diseases and their
          therapeutic modalities.

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt

      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on individual
          genes, but recent advancements in functional genomics suggest that a
          more comprehensive view of gene networks could provide valuable
          insights into disease etiology and drug mechanisms. 


          **Content:** We introduce PhenoPLIER, an 'omnigenic' method that
          integrates different data modalities into a joint analysis by
          representing them in a shared latent space. This approach allows us to
          infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex
          traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among
          traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological perturbations on
          gene activity. By mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into this common latent representation, we
          observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types. For instance, hypothyroidism is
          associated with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry
          measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types,
          plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with
          different brain cell types. Our method can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We validate our findings by replicating significant module-trait
          associations in the eMERGE network phase III from our discovery
          cohort, PhenomeXcan. Furthermore, a CRISPR screen in HepG2 cells
          reveals more robust trait associations with modules than with
          individual genes, suggesting that modules may offer a better means to
          examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


          **Conclusion:** By incorporating groups of genes acting together in
          specific cell types, PhenoPLIER improves the robustness of detecting
          and interpreting genetic associations. This novel approach provides a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, enabling
          the extraction of mechanistic insights from statistical associations
          to enhance our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities. (Utilized references: [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083],
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72],
          [@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225])

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)

          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in

          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies often focus on individual genes, but a
          more nuanced perspective considers how groups of functionally-related
          genes influence complex traits. This is where PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic
          approach, comes into play. It provides a gene module viewpoint for
          genetic research.


          **Content:** PhenoPLIER integrates different data types into a joint
          analysis by creating a shared representation. By mapping gene-trait
          associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common
          latent space, it utilizes thousands of gene-trait associations from
          TWAS (PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional profiles of drugs from LINCS
          L1000. This information is embedded in a low-dimensional space learned
          from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq
          samples (recount2). A matrix factorization approach defines the latent
          representation, extracting gene modules with sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge such as
          pathways.


          When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space,
          diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
          relevant cell types. For example, hypothyroidism is linked with T
          cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
          hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with
          adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain
          cell types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated
          with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.


          In a CRISPR screen for lipid regulation in HepG2 cells, trait
          associations were more robust with modules than with individual genes,
          even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did
          not reach genome-wide significance. This module-based method better
          predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
          pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of
          drugs.


          **Conclusion:** PhenoPLIER, by incorporating groups of genes acting
          together in specific cell types, improves robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations. This novel approach has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insights from statistical
          associations, ultimately enhancing our understanding of complex
          diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
          offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our approach has
          the flexibility to integrate various data modalities into a single
          representation, facilitating joint analysis. We demonstrate that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptional
          properties among traits, and predict the impact of pharmacological
          perturbations on gene activity.


          PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a common latent representation by
          integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from
          PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000)
          into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data
          on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We use a matrix
          factorization approach to define a latent representation that extracts
          gene modules with sparsity constraints and preferences for those that
          align with prior knowledge, such as pathways.


          When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space,
          we observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types, including hypothyroidism with T
          cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
          hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with
          adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain
          cell types. Additionally, PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated
          with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.


          Our results show that significant module-trait associations in
          PhenomeXcan replicate in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics
          (eMERGE) network phase III. A CRISPR screen analysis of lipid
          regulation in HepG2 cells reveals more robust trait associations with
          modules than with individual genes, suggesting that modules may
          provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than
          individual genes.


          Exploring the phenotype-module space uncovers stable trait clusters
          associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving
          lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders. By incorporating groups of genes that act together in
          specific cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations. This approach has the potential to
          extract mechanistic insights from statistical associations, improving
          our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

        id: >-
          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mixtral=8x7b-instruct-v0.1-q8_0
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on individual
          genes, but recent advances in functional genomics suggest that a more
          comprehensive view of gene networks can provide valuable insights into
          disease etiology and drug mechanisms. 


          **Content:** We introduce PhenoPLIER, an 'omnigenic' approach that
          integrates different data modalities into a joint analysis by
          representing them in a common latent space. This method allows us to
          infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence complex
          traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among
          traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological perturbations on
          gene activity. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
          drug-induced transcriptional responses into this shared latent space,
          using resources such as TWAS from PhenomeXcan, LINCS L1000, and
          recount2. Our analysis reveals that diseases are significantly
          associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, and
          these module-trait associations replicate in independent cohorts like
          the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics network. Furthermore, a
          CRISPR screen in HepG2 cells shows more robust trait associations with
          modules than with individual genes, suggesting that modules may offer
          a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than single
          genes.


          **Conclusion:** By incorporating groups of genes acting together in
          specific cell types, PhenoPLIER improves the robustness of detecting
          and interpreting genetic associations. This novel approach not only
          highlights alternative candidate targets when known single gene
          associations are not detected but also extracts mechanistic insights
          from statistical associations, ultimately enhancing our understanding
          of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities. (Keywords:
          genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic
          targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits; References:
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083], [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049],
          [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1],
          [@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225])

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies often focus on individual genes,
          neglecting the collective influence of functionally-related gene
          groups on complex traits. To address this limitation, we introduce
          PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that provides a gene module
          perspective to genetic studies.


          **Content:** PhenoPLIER integrates different data modalities into a
          joint analysis by mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. This is
          achieved through the integration of thousands of gene-trait
          associations from TWAS in PhenomeXcan, transcriptional profiles of
          drugs from LINCS L1000, and public gene expression data on tens of
          thousands of RNA-seq samples from recount2 into a low-dimensional
          space. The latent representation is defined by a matrix factorization
          approach that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints
          and preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
          We have observed that diseases are significantly associated with gene
          modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with
          T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
          hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with
          adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain
          cell types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated
          with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states, revealing
          robust trait associations with modules compared to individual genes.


          **Conclusion:** Our module-based method better predicts FDA-approved
          drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological
          mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs. This improved
          drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a better
          means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. By
          incorporating groups of genes that act together in specific cell
          types, PhenoPLIER improves robustness in detecting and interpreting
          genetic associations, potentially extracting mechanistic insight from
          statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex
          diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
