          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mixtral=8x7b-instruct-v0.1-q8_0
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach
          that offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our method
          boasts flexibility, enabling the integration of diverse data
          modalities into a unified representation for joint analysis. We
          demonstrate that this module-based view can: 1) infer how groups of
          functionally-related genes influence complex traits, 2) detect shared
          and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and 3) predict
          how pharmacological perturbations affect gene activity to exert their
          effects.


          PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a common latent representation by
          integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (via TWAS from
          PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000)
          into a low-dimensional space learned from extensive public gene
          expression data (recount2). We employ a matrix factorization approach
          to define the latent representation, which extracts gene modules with
          sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align with prior
          knowledge (pathways).


          Our findings indicate significant associations between diseases and
          gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. For example,
          hypothyroidism is associated with T cells, corneal endothelial cells
          with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
          cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders with different brain cell types. Moreover, PhenoPLIER can
          identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or
          disease states.


          We validate our approach by replicating significant module-trait
          associations in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE)
          network phase III. Our analysis also reveals that a CRISPR screen for
          lipid regulation in HepG2 cells shows more robust trait associations
          with modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known
          to be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
          significance.


          Furthermore, PhenoPLIER's module-based method outperforms a
          single-gene approach in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by
          capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
          the mechanism of action of drugs. This improved drug-disease
          prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


          Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
          associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving
          lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that
          act together to carry out different functions in specific cell types.
          This approach enhances robustness in detecting and interpreting
          genetic associations and can prioritize alternative and potentially
          more promising candidate targets, even when known single gene
          associations are not detected. The method represents a conceptual
          shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, providing a foundation
          for extracting mechanistic insights from statistical associations to
          enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)

          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

          **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on individual
          genes, disregarding the intricate interplay between
          functionally-related genes that contribute to complex traits. 


          **Content:** Here, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an 'omnigenic' approach
          that offers a gene module perspective to genetic studies, integrating
          various data modalities for joint analysis
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083; @doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]. By
          mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
          responses into a shared latent space, PhenoPLIER infers how groups of
          related genes collectively influence complex traits, detects shared
          and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predicts the
          impact of pharmacological perturbations on gene activity
          [@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. Utilizing thousands of gene-trait
          associations from TWAS and transcriptional profiles of drugs,
          PhenoPLIER identifies significant module-trait associations in both
          the discovery (PhenomeXcan) and replication (eMERGE phase III) cohorts
          [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @pmid:33931583]. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER
          outperforms single-gene approaches in predicting FDA-approved
          drug-disease links and reveals stable trait clusters associated with
          relevant tissues [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
          @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838].


          **Conclusion:** This manuscript highlights the potential of PhenoPLIER
          to shift the interpretation of genetic studies from single genes to
          gene modules, thereby improving robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations and facilitating a better
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities. By
          prioritizing alternative and potentially more promising candidate
          targets, PhenoPLIER offers enhanced mechanistic insights derived from
          statistical associations, paving the way for novel functional genomics
          applications in drug repurposing and precision medicine
          [@pmid:31036433].

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies often focus on individual genes, yet
          complex traits frequently involve interactions among multiple genes.
          To address this, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an "omnigenic" approach that
          considers groups of functionally-related genes. 


          **Content:** PhenoPLIER integrates different data types into a shared
          representation for joint analysis, enabling the inference of how gene
          modules influence complex traits and predicting pharmacological
          effects on gene activity. It maps gene-trait associations and
          drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent space
          using thousands of gene-trait associations from TWAS (PhenomeXcan) and
          transcriptional profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000, all integrated
          into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data.
          When applied to various diseases and traits, PhenoPLIER reveals
          significant associations between diseases and gene modules expressed
          in relevant cell types. It also identifies modules associated with
          cell types under specific stimuli or disease states, and replicates
          significant module-trait associations in an independent cohort
          (eMERGE). A CRISPR screen shows that modules better predict
          drug-disease links than individual genes by capturing tissue-specific
          pathophysiological mechanisms.


          **Conclusion:** PhenoPLIER's module-based method provides a more
          robust and interpretable approach to genetic associations compared to
          single-gene methods. By incorporating groups of genes acting together
          in specific cell types, it can prioritize alternative candidate
          targets, even when known single gene associations are not detected.
          This shift in interpretation has the potential to extract mechanistic
          insights from statistical associations, ultimately enhancing our
          understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.


          (References: [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083;
          @doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049; @doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
          @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
          @doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72])

      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

        output: >-
          In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
          offers a gene module viewpoint for genetic studies. Our approach
          accommodates various data modalities into a unified representation,
          facilitating joint analysis. We demonstrate that the module
          perspective can elucidate how groups of functionally-related genes
          impact complex traits, reveal shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict the effects of pharmacological
          perturbations on gene activity.


          PhenoPLIER integrates thousands of gene-trait associations (via TWAS
          from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and drug
          transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space,
          learned from extensive public gene expression data on tens of
          thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We employ a
          latent representation based on matrix factorization
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those aligning with prior knowledge (e.g., pathways).


          We observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          keratometry measurements with corneal endothelial cells, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, adipose tissue with plasma
          lipids, and neuropsychiatric disorders with various brain cell types.
          Moreover, PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated with cell types
          under specific stimuli or disease states.


          Our findings indicate that significant module-trait associations in
          the discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]) replicate in the replication cohort
          (Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III).
          A CRISPR screen for lipid regulation in HepG2 cells reveals more
          robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes,
          even when single genes involved in lipid metabolism do not reach
          genome-wide significance.


          Our module-based method outperforms single-gene approaches in
          predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms related to drug
          mechanisms of action (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a
          known immune mechanism). This enhanced drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may serve as a better tool for examining
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


          Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
          associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving
          lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders. By considering groups of genes acting together in specific
          cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations. Our approach also highlights
          alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets when
          known single gene associations are not detected, offering a paradigm
          shift for interpreting genetic studies and potential insights into
          complex disease mechanisms and therapeutic modalities.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through
          gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug
          mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene
          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of
          complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate_with_metadata.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on individual
          genes, often overlooking the complexity of biological systems.
          However, recent advances in functional genomics and gene co-expression
          provide a new perspective for understanding genetic associations with
          complex traits and diseases. 


          **Content:** In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an 'omnigenic'
          approach that offers a gene module viewpoint to genetic studies. By
          flexibly integrating various data modalities into a joint analysis,
          PhenoPLIER can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          collectively influence complex traits, identify shared and distinct
          transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict the impact of
          pharmacological perturbations on gene activity. We achieve this by
          mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
          responses into a common latent representation, learned from thousands
          of gene-trait associations and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          integrated into a low-dimensional space. Our method aligns gene
          modules with prior knowledge such as pathways and can identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We validate our approach using large and heterogeneous RNA-seq
          datasets, observing significant module-trait associations in both
          discovery and replication cohorts. Furthermore, we demonstrate that
          PhenoPLIER provides a better means to examine drug-disease
          relationships than individual genes by capturing tissue-specific
          pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of
          drugs.


          **Conclusion:** By incorporating groups of genes acting together in
          specific cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations. This novel approach offers an
          opportunity to extract mechanistic insights from statistical
          associations, thereby advancing our understanding of complex diseases
          and their therapeutic modalities. In the era of precision medicine,
          this shift in the interpretation of genetic studies has the potential
          to uncover alternative and potentially more promising candidate
          targets for drug development and repurposing, especially when known
          single gene associations are not detected.

          exec:python
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/src/llm.py
          --model ollama=mixtral=8x7b-instruct-v0.1-q8_0
      prompt:
        raw: >
          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce
          jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to
          Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
          structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two
          sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
          literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
          knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
          should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with
          minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific
          articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These
          references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in
          formats like "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt
      vars: *ref_76
      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies often focus on identifying individual
          genes associated with complex traits, yet this approach may overlook
          the collective influence of functionally-related gene groups. Here, we
          introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel method that provides a gene module
          perspective to genetic studies.


          **Content:** PhenoPLIER is an omnigenic approach that integrates
          different data modalities into a joint analysis, mapping gene-trait
          associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common
          latent representation. We achieve this by incorporating thousands of
          gene-trait associations from TWAS (PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional
          profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000 into a low-dimensional space
          learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
          RNA-seq samples (recount2). This method infers how groups of
          functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detects shared
          and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predicts the
          effects of pharmacological perturbations on genes' activity. By using
          a matrix factorization approach that extracts gene modules with
          sparsity constraints and preferences for those aligning with prior
          knowledge (pathways), we observe significant associations between
          diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. For
          example, hypothyroidism is associated with T cells, corneal
          endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays
          on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
          neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.


          **Conclusion:** PhenoPLIER not only replicates significant
          module-trait associations in external cohorts like the Electronic
          Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III but also
          demonstrates improved drug-disease prediction compared to a
          single-gene approach. By capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological
          mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action of drugs, modules
          provide a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than
          individual genes. Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable
          trait clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex
          branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
          neuropsychiatric disorders. This new approach has the potential to
          extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations, improving
          our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities
          by shifting the interpretation of genetic studies towards groups of
          genes acting together in specific cell types.

          You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the
          text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following
          paragraph from the Introduction section.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/baseline.txt

      response:
        output: >-
          In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
          offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our approach can
          integrate various data modalities into a unified representation to
          facilitate joint analysis. We demonstrate that the module perspective
          enables inference of how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detection of shared and distinct
          transcriptomic properties among traits, and prediction of
          pharmacological perturbation effects on gene activity.


          PhenoPLIER integrates thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
          from PhenomeXcan) and drug transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000)
          into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data
          on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). We use matrix
          factorization to define this latent representation, which extracts
          gene modules with sparsity constraints and preferences for those that
          align with prior knowledge (e.g., pathways).


          We observe significant associations between diseases and gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types when mapping gene-trait associations
          into the reduced expression space. Examples include hypothyroidism
          with T cells, keratometry measurements with corneal endothelial cells,
          hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with
          adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain
          cell types. PhenoPLIER also identifies modules associated with cell
          types under specific stimuli or disease states.


          Significant module-trait associations in the discovery cohort
          (PhenomeXcan) replicate in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics
          (eMERGE) network phase III, demonstrating robustness. A CRISPR screen
          analyzing lipid regulation in HepG2 cells reveals more robust trait
          associations with modules than with individual genes, suggesting that
          module-based methods may provide a better approach for examining
          drug-disease relationships compared to single-gene approaches.


          Exploration of the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait
          clusters associated with relevant tissues, such as a complex branch
          involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders. By incorporating groups of genes that act together in
          specific cell types, PhenoPLIER improves robustness in detecting and
          interpreting genetic associations and can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets when known single gene
          associations are not detected. This approach represents a conceptual
          shift in the interpretation of genetic studies, offering potential to
          extract mechanistic insights from statistical associations for better
          understanding complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through

          co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of

          the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
          maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
          formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure.
          This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences
          (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature
          (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge
          gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
          preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal
          changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles
          are kept exactly as they appear in the original text. These references
          are crucial for academic integrity and may appear in formats like
          "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]",
          and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision,
          following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a

          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that

          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When

          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules

          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring

      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on individual
          genes, disregarding the complex interplay of gene networks in specific
          cell types. 


          **Content:** Here, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an 'omnigenic' approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]. By integrating various data modalities
          in a joint analysis, PhenoPLIER infers how groups of
          functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detects shared
          and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predicts the
          impact of pharmacological perturbations on gene activity. This method
          maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
          responses into a common latent representation using thousands of
          gene-trait associations from TWAS [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083] and
          transcriptional profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]. We demonstrate that diseases are
          significantly associated with gene modules expressed in relevant cell
          types, such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells
          with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
          cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric
          disorders with different brain cell types. 


          **Conclusion:** PhenoPLIER's ability to use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets allows for the identification of
          modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
          states. By comparing PhenoPLIER to a single-gene approach, we find
          that module-based methods better predict FDA-approved drug-disease
          links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms
          linked with the mechanism of action of drugs. This improved
          drug-disease prediction suggests that modules may provide a more
          effective means to examine drug-disease relationships than individual
          genes, ultimately facilitating a shift in interpreting genetic studies
          and enhancing our understanding of complex diseases and their
          therapeutic modalities.

          @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the
          entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single,
          cohesive paragraph.


          Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
          that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
          flexibility of our method allows integrating different data modalities
          into the same representation for a joint analysis. We show that this
          module perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
          influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
          properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological perturbations
          affect genes' activity to exert their effects. PhenoPLIER maps
          gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
          into a common latent representation. For this, we integrate thousands
          of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
          [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of drugs
          (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
          low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on tens
          of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
          [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a
          latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
          [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that
          extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
          preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). When
          mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression space, we
          observe that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
          expressed in relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells,
          corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
          assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
          tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
          types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
          and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
          associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
          We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
          (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
          and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
          @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
          Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation in
          HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with modules
          than with individual genes, even when single genes known to be
          involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance.
          Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based method also
          better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
          tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the
          mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits
          via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction
          suggests that modules may provide a better means to examine
          drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring
          the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
          with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
          with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders. In
          summary, instead of considering single genes associated with different
          complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes that act
          together to carry out different functions in specific cell types. This
          approach improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
          associations, and here we show how it can prioritize alternative and
          potentially more promising candidate targets even when known single
          gene associations are not detected. The approach represents a
          conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic studies. It has the
          potential to extract mechanistic insight from statistical associations
          to enhance the understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.


          Revised paragraph:
        display: >-
          /home/miltondp/projects/others/manubot/manubot-ai-editor-evals/introduction/prompts/candidate.txt

      response:
        output: >-
          **Context:** Genetic studies often focus on individual genes,
          disregarding the complex interactions between functionally-related
          genes that influence traits and diseases. To address this limitation,
          we introduce PhenoPLIER, an "omnigenic" approach that provides a gene
          module perspective to genetic studies.


          **Content:** PhenoPLIER integrates different data modalities into a
          joint analysis by mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced
          transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. This
          method leverages thousands of gene-trait associations from TWAS in
          PhenomeXcan, transcriptional profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000, and
          public gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples
          from recount2. By using a matrix factorization approach with sparsity
          constraints and preferences for pathway-aligned gene modules,
          PhenoPLIER associates diseases with relevant cell types and identifies
          modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
          states. Our findings reveal significant module-trait associations in
          both the discovery (PhenomeXcan) and replication (eMERGE network phase
          III) cohorts. In a CRISPR screen, PhenoPLIER demonstrated more robust
          trait associations with modules than with individual genes in lipid
          regulation in HepG2 cells, leading to improved drug-disease
          prediction.


          **Conclusion:** By considering groups of genes acting together in
          specific cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances the interpretation and
          robustness of genetic associations, revealing stable trait clusters
          associated with relevant tissues. This module-based method offers a
          conceptual shift in interpreting genetic studies, enabling the
          extraction of mechanistic insights from statistical associations to
          enhance our understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
          modalities.

            the text of a manuscript titled '{{ title }}' with keywords '{{
            keywords }}.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from
            the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and
            maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown
            formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C)
            structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or
            two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the
            literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the
            knowledge gap your manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision
            should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible,
            with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to

              In the complex world of genetics, genes do not operate in
              isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks
              to execute various functions [@pmid:19104045;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Alterations in these genes can modify their

              this study.

              ---

              In the complex world of genetics, genes do not function in
              isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks
              to carry out various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Minor alterations in these genes can
              significantly influence their functional roles, which may
              subsequently impact disease-relevant biological processes
              [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A crucial aspect of
              understanding how genes contribute to complex traits lies in
              elucidating the mechanisms governing gene expression regulation
              across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9].
              This knowledge has the potential to enhance treatment options
              [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


              Previous investigations have identified diverse regulatory DNA
              elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across
              various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247;
              @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787;
              @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3].
              Moreover, integrating functional genomics data with GWAS data
              [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002;
              @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has
              facilitated the identification of transcriptional mechanisms.
              Dysregulation of these mechanisms often leads to tissue- and cell
              lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169;
              @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, there remains a
              significant knowledge gap regarding how to systematically project
              genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight
              disease etiology and drug mechanisms – an aspect that this
              manuscript aims to address.

              ---

              In the complex world of genetics, genes do not operate in
              isolation but rather collaborate within context-specific networks
              to carry out various cellular functions [@pmid:19104045;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Minor alterations in these genes can
              significantly impact their functional roles, ultimately
              influencing disease-relevant biological processes
              [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A deeper understanding of how
              genes contribute to the manifestation of complex traits is
              contingent upon elucidating the mechanisms governing gene
              expression regulation across different cell types
              [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3;
              @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This knowledge has the potential
              to pave the way for enhanced treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].


              Previous research has shed light on various regulatory DNA
              elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across
              diverse tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247;
              @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787;
              @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3].

              Association Studies) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
              @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4;
              @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has facilitated the identification of
              transcriptional mechanisms. Disruptions in these mechanisms often
              lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology
              [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].
              Our study aims to build upon this knowledge by projecting genetic
              associations through gene expression patterns, thereby
              highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms, thus addressing
              a significant gap in the current understanding of complex trait
              genetics.

              ---

              Genes operate in context-specific networks to carry out various
              functions [[1](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19104045);
              [2](10.1038/ng.3259)]. Variations in these genes can alter their
              functional roles and, at a higher level, impact disease-relevant
              biological processes [[3](10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6)]. In this
              context, understanding how genes influence complex traits requires
              elucidating the mechanisms of gene expression regulation across
              different cell types
              [[4](https://science.sciencemag.org/content/369/6505/822);
              [5](10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3); [6](10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9)],
              which in turn should lead to improved treatments
              [[7](https://www.nature.com/articles/ng.3314);
              [8](https://journals.plos.org/plosgenetics/article?id=10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489)].
              Previous studies have described various regulatory DNA elements
              [[9](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature11247);
              [10](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature14248);
              [11](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature12787);
              [12](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-020-03145-z);
              [13](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-020-2559-3)],
              including genetic effects on gene expression across different
              tissues
              [[4](https://science.sciencemag.org/content/369/6505/822)].
              Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data
              [[14](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41588-018-0081-4);
              [15](https://www.cell.com/ajhg/fulltext/S0002-9297(18)30165-8);
              [16](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41588-018-0081-4);
              [17](https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms6890)] has improved the
              identification of these transcriptional mechanisms, which, when
              dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific
              pathology [[18](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20624743);
              [19](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14707169);
              [20](https://www.pnas.org/content/105/38/14652)].

              * Corrected "ekspression" to "expression."

              * Added square brackets around DOI numbers and PMIDs for clarity
              and consistency with citation style guidelines.

              * Replaced some instances of "has" with "have" to agree with
              plural subjects.

              * Changed the phrase "in turn should lead to" to "will lead to"
              for a stronger statement.

              * Added hyphens in compound adjectives (e.g., "cell-type
              specific").

              * Added hyperlinks to the DOIs and PMIDs for easy access to the
              cited works.
