              Context: Genes function in a coordinated manner within
              context-specific networks to execute various biological roles
              [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes
              can alter their functional impact, ultimately affecting
              disease-relevant processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. A

              on elucidating the regulation of gene expression across different
              cell types, which could potentially lead to improved treatments
              [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489].

              elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across
              different tissues [@doi:10.1038/nature11247;

              transcriptional mechanisms. Dysregulation of these mechanisms
              often leads to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology
              [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

              understanding of how gene expression patterns and their regulation
              contribute to disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains
              elusive. This manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by
              projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns,
              highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms, with a focus on
              the clustering of complex traits (keywords). By employing a
              systems biology approach that combines genomics, transcriptomics,
              and bioinformatics, we aim to reveal novel insights into the
              intricate interplay between genetic variations, gene expression
              regulation, and disease pathophysiology. This enhanced
              understanding could facilitate the identification of therapeutic
              targets and the repurposing of existing drugs, ultimately
              improving patient outcomes.

              context-specific networks to execute various cellular activities

            text: >-
              The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various
              tissues provides an opportunity to identify biological processes
              effectively [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A powerful approach to achieve
              this is through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS),
              which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
              to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. TWAS
              functions by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This method has been highly successful in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              and in disease-risk prediction, including polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], as well as drug repurposing
              tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the
              individual gene level, thereby overlooking more complex
              interactions at the network level.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly
              successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in
              disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for innovative approaches to identify biological
              processes associated with diseases. 


              Content: A prominent method in this regard is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
              mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              TWAS functions by examining whether disturbances in gene
              regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has not only enhanced our
              understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              but also proven beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic
              scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


              Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS at the individual gene
              level, it fails to capture more intricate interactions at the
              network level. Our manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by
              employing a systems biology approach that considers gene
              co-expression and clustering of complex traits, thereby refining
              the projection of genetic associations through gene expression
              patterns and shedding light on disease etiology and drug
              mechanisms.

              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining

              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to

              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative

              for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;

              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes underlying human diseases. 


              Content: One such method, termed transcription-wide association
              study (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci
              (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide
              association studies (GWAS) findings by testing whether
              perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link
              between genetic variants and diseases [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has
              proven successful in understanding disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level and in disease-risk prediction (polygenic
              scores) as well as drug repurposing tasks [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433;
              @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


              Conclusion: Despite its success, TWAS operates at the individual
              gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the
              network level. Our manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by
              presenting a novel approach that captures complex
              disease-associated genetic networks, offering a more comprehensive
              understanding of disease etiology and potential therapeutic
              targets.

            whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
            association between genetic variants and human diseases
            [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

            disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
            [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
            [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual

              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes underlying human diseases. 


              Content: A prominent method in this regard is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
              mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              TWAS operates by testing whether disturbances in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              approach has not only enhanced our understanding of disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also proven
              beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


              Conclusion: Despite these advances, TWAS focuses on individual
              gene analysis, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at
              the network level. Our study aims to address this knowledge gap by
              projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns,
              which will shed light on disease etiology and drug mechanisms from
              a systems biology perspective.

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel methods to identify biological
              processes associated with diseases. 


              Content: A prominent approach is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of
              GWAS findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the link between genetic variants and human
              diseases. TWAS has been successful not only in elucidating disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level but also in predicting disease
              risk (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks. However, this
              method focuses on individual gene-level analysis, thereby
              overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.


              Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success in identifying gene-level
              associations, there is a need to explore complex interactions at
              the network level to enhance our understanding of disease etiology
              and improve risk prediction and drug repurposing strategies. Our
              manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by proposing a novel
              approach that integrates TWAS with network analysis techniques.


              (References: [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across numerous
              tissues has paved the way for novel approaches to identify
              biological processes underlying human diseases.

              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates

              mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings by testing whether
              perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link

              @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w;
              @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual
              gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the
              network level.


              Conclusion: Our study aims to address this knowledge gap by
              projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns,
              thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms while
              considering complex interactions at the network level. This
              approach will facilitate a deeper understanding of the clustering
              of complex traits and therapeutic targets in the context of
              functional genomics.

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes underlying human diseases. One such method, the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), has garnered
              significant attention due to its ability to offer mechanistic
              insights into GWAS findings by integrating expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data.


              Content: TWAS functions by testing whether perturbations in gene
              regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has been highly successful in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              and has also contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic
              scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


              Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS in identifying individual
              gene contributions to disease, it does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level. Bridging this knowledge gap
              requires the development and implementation of methods that can
              model these intricate relationships, thereby advancing our
              understanding of disease pathophysiology and informing novel
              therapeutic strategies.

              The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various
              tissues provides an opportunity to investigate biological
              processes systematically [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A powerful approach to achieve

              which amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
              to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. TWAS
              focuses on examining whether alterations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and
              human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;

              elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              and has also contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic
              scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the
              individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate
              interactions at the network level.

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes associated with diseases. 


              Content: A prominent method in this regard is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
              mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9].
              TWAS operates by testing whether disturbances in gene regulatory
              mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and
              human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has achieved significant
              success in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              and has contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


              Conclusion: Despite the merits of TWAS, its focus on individual
              gene level interactions limits its ability to capture more
              intricate network-level interactions. Our manuscript addresses
              this knowledge gap by employing a systems biology approach that
              considers complex interactions among genes, thereby providing a
              deeper understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with

              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes. 


              Content: A prominent method in this regard is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
              mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings by testing whether
              disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between
              genetic variants and human diseases. This approach has achieved
              considerable success in elucidating disease etiology at the
              transcriptome level and has been instrumental in disease-risk
              prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks. However,
              TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking
              more intricate interactions at the network level.


              Conclusion: Despite its accomplishments, TWAS's limitation in
              capturing complex interactions at the network level underscores
              the need for further research to enhance our understanding of
              disease etiology and improve risk prediction and drug repurposing
              strategies. Our manuscript addresses this knowledge gap by
              proposing an innovative approach that integrates TWAS with
              network-level analysis, thereby potentially unlocking new insights
              into disease mechanisms and facilitating more effective
              therapeutic interventions. ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367;
              @pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433;
              @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618])

              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;

              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes underlying human diseases. 


              Content: A prominent method in this regard is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
              mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association studies
              (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS operates by testing whether
              disturbances in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
              between genetic variants and diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              approach has not only enhanced our understanding of disease
              etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also
              demonstrated success in disease-risk prediction, known as
              polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug
              repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].


              Conclusion: Despite TWAS's individual gene-level focus, which has
              proven beneficial in several aspects, it fails to capture more
              intricate network-level interactions. Our manuscript addresses
              this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene
              expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms at a systems level.

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes underlying human diseases. 


              Content: A notable method in this regard is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which combines expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data with GWAS findings to offer a mechanistic
              interpretation of genetic variants' role in disease etiology
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has
              achieved remarkable success in explaining disease
              transcriptome-level mechanisms [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk
              prediction through polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. 


              Conclusion: Despite TWAS' individual gene level focus, which has
              proven successful in several applications, there remains a need to
              explore more complex interactions at the network level,
              highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap this manuscript aims
              to address.

              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the
              individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
              interactions at the network level.

              ---

              Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type of
              genetic investigation that aims to understand if alterations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms play a role in the relationship between
              genetic variants and human diseases
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Such
              approaches have been successful in several aspects, including
              elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk through polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundance of gene expression data
              across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has made TWAS a valuable tool, as
              it combines expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to
              offer a mechanistic interpretation for findings from genome-wide
              association studies (GWAS). Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the
              individual gene level, which may overlook more intricate
              interactions occurring at the network level. This limitation
              underscores the necessity of exploring methods that can capture
              these complexities in genetic associations, an aspect addressed by
              our manuscript as we delve into the analysis of gene co-expression
              and clustering of complex traits.


              Context:

              Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a
              valuable tool to understand if alterations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms play a role in the relationship between genetic
              variants and human diseases, with successful applications in
              disease etiology, risk prediction, and drug repurposing tasks.


              Content:

              The abundance of gene expression data across various tissues has
              made TWAS an even more powerful approach by combining expression
              quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic
              interpretation for findings from genome-wide association studies
              (GWAS). However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which
              may overlook more intricate interactions occurring at the network
              level.


              Conclusion:

              This limitation underscores the necessity of exploring methods
              that can capture these complexities in genetic associations, an
              aspect addressed by our manuscript as we delve into the analysis
              of gene co-expression and clustering of complex traits.

              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),

              ---

              Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a powerful tool
              in genomics, designed to examine the role of perturbations in gene
              regulatory mechanisms in the association between genetic variants
              and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been successful in
              understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              and have also been applied in disease-risk prediction (polygenic
              scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundance of gene expression data
              across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has led to the use of TWAS as an
              effective method to identify implicated biological processes. This
              approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for Genome-Wide
              Association Studies (GWAS) findings. However, a limitation of TWAS
              is that it operates at the individual gene level, thereby
              overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.


              In summary, while TWAS has proven to be a valuable tool in
              genomics research, its focus on individual gene-level analysis may
              result in the overlook of complex interactions at the network
              level. Our study aims to address this knowledge gap by exploring
              methods that can capture these intricate interactions and provide
              a more comprehensive understanding of the relationship between
              genetic variants and human diseases.

              ---

              Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type of
              genetic analysis that aims to understand the relationship between
              genetic variants and human diseases by examining perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has been successful in
              elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              and has been applied to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The abundance of gene expression data
              across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has facilitated the use of TWAS,
              which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
              to offer a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association
              studies (GWAS) findings. However, TWAS operates at the individual
              gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the
              network level. Bridging this knowledge gap by exploring higher
              levels of genetic organization and their relationship to disease
              etiology is a key objective of our manuscript.


              In summary, TWAS has proven to be a valuable tool in understanding
              disease etiology, predicting disease risk, and repurposing drugs
              through the examination of gene regulatory mechanisms. The
              availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues has
              further enhanced the utility of TWAS. Nevertheless, the current
              focus on individual genes leaves a gap in comprehending more
              complex network-level interactions, which our manuscript aims to
              address by projecting genetic associations through gene expression
              patterns and highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

              Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a powerful tool
              in genomics research, focusing on the impact of genetic variants
              on human diseases through alterations in gene regulatory
              mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;

              our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]
              and has been instrumental in disease-risk prediction, such as
              polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug

              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS, which incorporates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, offers a valuable
              method to explain GWAS findings mechanistically at the individual
              gene level. Nevertheless, TWAS does not account for more intricate
              interactions at the network level, representing an area in need of
              further exploration.

              Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) focus on determining
              whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms underlie the

              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]; @pmid:31036433]) and has
              further contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]) and drug repurposing efforts
              ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). With the abundance of gene expression

              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6]; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776];
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]), TWAS offers an effective
              approach to identify implicated biological processes by
              integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data,

              individual gene level, which may overlook more intricate
              interactions at the network level.

              ---

              Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type of
              genetic investigation that aims to determine if alterations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms play a role in the association between
              genetic variants and human diseases
              (Doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482, Doi:10.1038/ng.3506,
              Doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889, Doi:10.1038/ng.3367). These
              studies have been successful in elucidating disease etiology at
              the transcriptome level (Pmid:33931583,
              Doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225, Pmid:31036433) and have also been
              applied to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              (Doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w) and drug repurposing tasks
              (Doi:10.1038/nn.4618). The abundance of gene expression data
              across various tissues (Doi:10.1038/nbt.3838,
              Doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6, Doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776,
              Doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9) has facilitated the use of TWAS in
              identifying biological processes. This approach integrates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
              mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. However, one
              limitation of TWAS is that it operates at the individual gene
              level, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the
              network level.


              In this manuscript, we aim to address this knowledge gap by
              proposing a novel approach that projects genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease
              etiology and drug mechanisms. Our method moves beyond the
              individual gene focus of TWAS to consider complex interactions at
              the network level, thus providing a more comprehensive
              understanding of the relationship between genetics and human
              diseases. By clustering complex traits and identifying therapeutic
              targets through functional genomics, our approach offers new
              possibilities for disease-risk prediction, drug repurposing, and
              the development of novel treatments.

              input = context["vars"]["content"]

              input_words = len(input.strip().split())

              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),

              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene
              level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
              network level.

              Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) focus on examining
              whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms underlie the
              association between genetic variants and human diseases

              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]; @pmid:31036433]) and has proven
              beneficial in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)

              ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). Given the abundance of gene expression

              ---

              Context: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type
              of genetic study that has been widely used to understand disease
              etiology and predict disease risk
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367;
              @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. These
              studies integrate gene expression data with genetic variants to
              identify genes associated with diseases.


              Content: TWAS has been successful in identifying biological
              processes at the transcriptome level and in disease-risk
              prediction tasks [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. With the
              availability of gene expression data across several tissues
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9],
              TWAS has become an effective approach to provide a mechanistic
              interpretation for GWAS findings by integrating expression
              quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. However, current TWAS
              approaches mainly focus on individual gene level analysis and do
              not capture more complex interactions at the network level.


              Conclusion: This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by
              proposing a novel approach that projects genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology
              and drug mechanisms at the network level. By clustering complex
              traits [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433], our method aims to identify therapeutic targets
              and facilitate drug repurposing, thereby advancing the field of
              functional genomics and precision medicine.

              The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various
              tissues provides an opportunity to identify biological processes
              effectively [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A promising approach to achieve
              this is through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS),
              which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
              to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings.
              Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby
              overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. TWAS
              methodologies involve testing whether perturbations in gene
              regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;

              successful in several areas. They have enhanced our understanding

              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], improved

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes associated with diseases at the molecular level. 


              Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association study
              (TWAS), amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs)
              data with GWAS findings to offer a mechanistic interpretation of
              these genetic associations [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. By testing whether alterations
              in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the link between genetic
              variants and human diseases, TWAS has proven successful in
              comprehending disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367] and has
              contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Nevertheless, TWAS primarily focuses on
              individual gene level analysis, overlooking more intricate
              interactions at the network level.


              Conclusion: Our manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by
              projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns,
              emphasizing not only single gene-based but also gene co-expression
              and clustering of complex traits [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. This
              comprehensive strategy will shed light on disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms, further advancing functional genomics and
              therapeutic target discovery.

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes associated with human diseases. 


              Content: A notable method, transcription-wide association studies
              (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data
              to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings by testing
              whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the
              association between genetic variants and diseases
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has

              transcriptome level and has contributed to disease-risk prediction
              (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug
              repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on
              individual gene level analysis, which may overlook more complex
              interactions at the network level.


              Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires the development
              of methods that can effectively capture and interpret the
              intricate interplay among genes within biological networks,
              thereby providing a comprehensive understanding of disease
              etiology and facilitating the discovery of novel therapeutic
              targets.

              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological

              etiology but also contributed to disease-risk prediction
              (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug
              repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS's reliance on
              individual gene-level analysis may overlook intricate interactions
              at the network level.

              a novel framework that projects genetic associations through gene

              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes, offering valuable insights into disease etiology and
              potential therapeutic interventions. 


              Content: A prominent method in this field is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS)
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. By
              integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS
              provides a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association
              study (GWAS) findings at the individual gene level. This approach
              has been highly successful in understanding disease mechanisms at
              the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and has
              contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores)
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual
              gene-level associations and does not account for more intricate
              interactions at the network level.


              Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires the development
              of methods that can capture complex genetic interactions at the
              network level, thereby providing a more comprehensive
              understanding of disease etiology and potential therapeutic
              targets [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Our
              manuscript aims to address this need by presenting a novel
              approach that integrates TWAS with gene network analysis, thereby
              enhancing the interpretation and utility of GWAS findings.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological
              processes underlying human diseases. 


              Content: A prominent method in this regard is the
              transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which amalgamates
              expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a
              mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings at the individual gene
              level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;
              @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. By
              testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms
              mediate the association between genetic variants and human
              diseases, TWAS has achieved remarkable success in comprehending
              disease etiology at the transcriptome level
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367;
              @pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433].
              This approach has also proven beneficial in disease-risk
              prediction, commonly known as polygenic scores
              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing tasks
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS primarily focuses on
              individual gene-level associations, thereby overlooking more
              intricate interactions at the network level.


              Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap, our manuscript introduces
              a novel method that projects genetic associations onto gene
              expression patterns to elucidate complex trait architectures and
              identify therapeutic targets by capitalizing on gene co-expression
              networks. This strategy not only enhances our understanding of
              disease etiology and drug mechanisms but also facilitates the
              clustering of complex traits, thereby providing a more
              comprehensive framework for genetic studies and functional
              genomics research.

              ---

              Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues
              has paved the way for sophisticated analytical techniques to
              identify biological processes underlying human diseases. 


              Content: A prominent approach, transcription-wide association
              studies (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci
              (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS
              findings by testing perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms at
              the individual gene level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. This method has been successful
              not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome
              level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic
              scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS focuses on individual
              gene-level analysis, thereby overlooking more complex interactions
              at the network level.


              Conclusion: Despite the success of TWAS in interpreting GWAS
              findings and its applications in disease risk prediction and drug
              repurposing, there is a need to address the knowledge gap
              concerning the detection of intricate interactions at the network
              level in gene regulatory mechanisms
              [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;
              @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This
              unmet need presents an opportunity for the current manuscript to
              contribute to the field by proposing novel methods or refining
              existing ones to capture these complexities in gene regulatory
              networks.

              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the

              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The

              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with

              Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data
              across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776;
              @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to
              identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide
              association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative
              trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation
              for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene
              level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the
              network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in
              gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic
              variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482;
              @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889;

              [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing
              [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

            Given the availability of gene expression data across several
            tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6;

            effective approach to identify these biological processes is the
            transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates
            expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a
            mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at
            the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex
            interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether
            perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association
            between genetic variants and human diseases
            [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506;

            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              We introduce PhenoPLIER, a comprehensive method that offers an
              omnigenic view for genetic studies by considering gene modules.
              Our approach integrates various data modalities into a unified
              representation, facilitating joint analysis. We demonstrate that
              this module-based perspective can infer how groups of functionally
              related genes influence complex traits, identify shared and
              distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict the
              impact of pharmacological perturbations on gene activity.


              PhenoPLIER represents gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses in a shared latent space. To achieve
              this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations from TWAS
              in PhenomeXcan and transcriptional profiles of drugs from LINCS
              L1000 into a low-dimensional space, which is learned from publicly
              available gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq
              samples in recount2. We use a matrix factorization approach to
              define the latent representation, focusing on extracting gene
              modules with sparsity constraints and preferences for those that
              align with prior knowledge (e.g., pathways).


              When mapping gene-trait associations into this reduced expression
              space, we observe significant connections between diseases and
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. Examples include
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated with cell
              types under specific stimuli or disease states.


              We validate our approach by comparing significant module-trait
              associations in the discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan) with those in
              the replication cohort (Electronic Medical Records and Genomics
              network phase III). Our results indicate that modules provide a
              more robust means to examine drug-disease relationships than
              individual genes.


              Additionally, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid
              regulation in HepG2 cells. We find that modules have stronger
              trait associations than individual genes, even when single genes
              involved in lipid metabolism do not reach genome-wide
              significance. Our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms related to the mechanism of action
              of drugs.


              Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
              associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
              involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates
              groups of genes acting together in specific cell types, enhancing
              robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations.
              This approach offers the potential to extract mechanistic insights
              from statistical associations, ultimately improving our
              understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
              modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              ---

              **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on
              individual genes, but recent advancements in functional genomics
              suggest that a more comprehensive view of gene networks could
              provide valuable insights into disease etiology and drug
              mechanisms. 


              **Content:** We introduce PhenoPLIER, an 'omnigenic' method that
              integrates different data modalities into a joint analysis by
              representing them in a shared latent space. This approach allows
              us to infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence
              complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
              properties among traits, and predict the effects of
              pharmacological perturbations on gene activity. By mapping
              gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
              into this common latent representation, we observe significant
              associations between diseases and gene modules expressed in
              relevant cell types. For instance, hypothyroidism is associated
              with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry
              measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types,
              plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders
              with different brain cell types. Our method can also identify
              modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or
              disease states. We validate our findings by replicating
              significant module-trait associations in the eMERGE network phase
              III from our discovery cohort, PhenomeXcan. Furthermore, a CRISPR
              screen in HepG2 cells reveals more robust trait associations with
              modules than with individual genes, suggesting that modules may
              offer a better means to examine drug-disease relationships than
              individual genes.


              **Conclusion:** By incorporating groups of genes acting together
              in specific cell types, PhenoPLIER improves the robustness of
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations. This novel
              approach provides a conceptual shift in the interpretation of
              genetic studies, enabling the extraction of mechanistic insights
              from statistical associations to enhance our understanding of
              complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities. (Utilized
              references: [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083],
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049], [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72],
              [@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225])

              **Context:** Genetic studies often focus on individual genes, but
              a more nuanced perspective considers how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits. This is where
              PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach, comes into play. It provides a
              gene module viewpoint for genetic research.


              **Content:** PhenoPLIER integrates different data types into a
              joint analysis by creating a shared representation. By mapping
              gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
              into a common latent space, it utilizes thousands of gene-trait
              associations from TWAS (PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional profiles
              of drugs from LINCS L1000. This information is embedded in a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2). A matrix
              factorization approach defines the latent representation,
              extracting gene modules with sparsity constraints and preferences
              for those that align with prior knowledge such as pathways.

              space, diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
              expressed in relevant cell types. For example, hypothyroidism is
              linked with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry
              measurements, hematological assays on specific blood cell types,
              plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders
              with different brain cell types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can
              identify modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli
              or disease states.

              associations were more robust with modules than with individual
              genes, even when single genes known to be involved in lipid
              metabolism did not reach genome-wide significance. This
              module-based method better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease
              links by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms
              linked with the mechanism of action of drugs.


              **Conclusion:** PhenoPLIER, by incorporating groups of genes
              acting together in specific cell types, improves robustness in
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations. This novel
              approach has the potential to extract mechanistic insights from
              statistical associations, ultimately enhancing our understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data

              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan

              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our

              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust

              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene

              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific

              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests

              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.

              that act together to carry out different functions in specific

            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
          - >-
            genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression,
            therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
          - has proper last paragraph structure
          - >-
            Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns
            highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
