            namedScores: *ref_80
            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
              offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our approach
              has the flexibility to integrate various data modalities into a
              single representation, facilitating joint analysis. We demonstrate
              that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptional properties among traits, and predict
              the impact of pharmacological perturbations on gene activity.


              PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a common latent representation by
              integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS from
              PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS
              L1000) into a low-dimensional space learned from public gene
              expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples
              (recount2). We use a matrix factorization approach to define a
              latent representation that extracts gene modules with sparsity
              constraints and preferences for those that align with prior
              knowledge, such as pathways.


              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe significant associations between diseases and
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types, including
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Additionally, PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated with cell
              types under specific stimuli or disease states.


              Our results show that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan replicate in the Electronic Medical Records and
              Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III. A CRISPR screen analysis of
              lipid regulation in HepG2 cells reveals more robust trait
              associations with modules than with individual genes, suggesting
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes.


              Exploring the phenotype-module space uncovers stable trait
              clusters associated with relevant tissues, including a complex
              branch involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. By incorporating groups of genes that
              act together in specific cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances
              robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations.
              This approach has the potential to extract mechanistic insights
              from statistical associations, improving our understanding of
              complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              ---

              **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on
              individual genes, but recent advances in functional genomics
              suggest that a more comprehensive view of gene networks can
              provide valuable insights into disease etiology and drug
              mechanisms. 


              **Content:** We introduce PhenoPLIER, an 'omnigenic' approach that
              integrates different data modalities into a joint analysis by
              representing them in a common latent space. This method allows us
              to infer how groups of functionally-related genes influence
              complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
              properties among traits, and predict the effects of
              pharmacological perturbations on gene activity. PhenoPLIER maps
              gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses
              into this shared latent space, using resources such as TWAS from
              PhenomeXcan, LINCS L1000, and recount2. Our analysis reveals that
              diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed
              in relevant cell types, and these module-trait associations
              replicate in independent cohorts like the Electronic Medical
              Records and Genomics network. Furthermore, a CRISPR screen in
              HepG2 cells shows more robust trait associations with modules than
              with individual genes, suggesting that modules may offer a better
              means to examine drug-disease relationships than single genes.


              **Conclusion:** By incorporating groups of genes acting together
              in specific cell types, PhenoPLIER improves the robustness of
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations. This novel
              approach not only highlights alternative candidate targets when
              known single gene associations are not detected but also extracts
              mechanistic insights from statistical associations, ultimately
              enhancing our understanding of complex diseases and their
              therapeutic modalities. (Keywords: genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits; References:
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083], [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049],
              [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838], [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1],
              [@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225])
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional

              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              ---

              **Context:** Genetic studies often focus on individual genes,
              neglecting the collective influence of functionally-related gene
              groups on complex traits. To address this limitation, we introduce
              PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that provides a gene module
              perspective to genetic studies.


              **Content:** PhenoPLIER integrates different data modalities into
              a joint analysis by mapping gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. This is achieved through the integration of
              thousands of gene-trait associations from TWAS in PhenomeXcan,
              transcriptional profiles of drugs from LINCS L1000, and public
              gene expression data on tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples from
              recount2 into a low-dimensional space. The latent representation
              is defined by a matrix factorization approach that extracts gene
              modules with certain sparsity constraints and preferences for
              those that align with prior knowledge (pathways). We have observed
              that diseases are significantly associated with gene modules
              expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism with T
              cells, corneal endothelial cells with keratometry measurements,
              hematological assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids
              with adipose tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different
              brain cell types. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER can identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states, revealing robust trait associations with modules compared
              to individual genes.


              **Conclusion:** Our module-based method better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs. This improved drug-disease prediction suggests that
              modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. By incorporating groups of
              genes that act together in specific cell types, PhenoPLIER
              improves robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic
              associations, potentially extracting mechanistic insight from
              statistical associations to enhance the understanding of complex
              diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the

              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the

              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          - pass: false

            namedScores: *ref_83
            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, a novel omnigenic approach
              that offers a gene module perspective for genetic studies. Our
              method boasts flexibility, enabling the integration of diverse
              data modalities into a unified representation for joint analysis.
              We demonstrate that this module-based view can: 1) infer how
              groups of functionally-related genes influence complex traits, 2)
              detect shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits,
              and 3) predict how pharmacological perturbations affect gene
              activity to exert their effects.


              PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
              transcriptional responses into a common latent representation by
              integrating thousands of gene-trait associations (via TWAS from
              PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional profiles of drugs (from LINCS
              L1000) into a low-dimensional space learned from extensive public
              gene expression data (recount2). We employ a matrix factorization
              approach to define the latent representation, which extracts gene
              modules with sparsity constraints and preferences for those that
              align with prior knowledge (pathways).


              Our findings indicate significant associations between diseases
              and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. For example,
              hypothyroidism is associated with T cells, corneal endothelial
              cells with keratometry measurements, hematological assays on
              specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, PhenoPLIER can identify modules associated with cell
              types under specific stimuli or disease states.


              We validate our approach by replicating significant module-trait
              associations in the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics
              (eMERGE) network phase III. Our analysis also reveals that a
              CRISPR screen for lipid regulation in HepG2 cells shows more
              robust trait associations with modules than with individual genes,
              even when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism
              did not reach genome-wide significance.


              Furthermore, PhenoPLIER's module-based method outperforms a
              single-gene approach in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links
              by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked
              with the mechanism of action of drugs. This improved drug-disease
              prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
              examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


              Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
              associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
              involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, PhenoPLIER incorporates
              groups of genes that act together to carry out different functions
              in specific cell types. This approach enhances robustness in
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations and can prioritize
              alternative and potentially more promising candidate targets, even
              when known single gene associations are not detected. The method
              represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation of genetic
              studies, providing a foundation for extracting mechanistic
              insights from statistical associations to enhance the
              understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
              modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              ("PhenoPLIER" in output.split(".")[0])

              ---

              **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on
              individual genes, disregarding the intricate interplay between
              functionally-related genes that contribute to complex traits. 


              **Content:** Here, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an 'omnigenic'
              approach that offers a gene module perspective to genetic studies,
              integrating various data modalities for joint analysis
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083; @doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]. By
              mapping gene-trait associations and drug-induced transcriptional
              responses into a shared latent space, PhenoPLIER infers how groups
              of related genes collectively influence complex traits, detects
              shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and
              predicts the impact of pharmacological perturbations on gene
              activity [@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]. Utilizing thousands
              of gene-trait associations from TWAS and transcriptional profiles
              of drugs, PhenoPLIER identifies significant module-trait
              associations in both the discovery (PhenomeXcan) and replication
              (eMERGE phase III) cohorts [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @pmid:33931583]. Furthermore, PhenoPLIER outperforms single-gene
              approaches in predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links and
              reveals stable trait clusters associated with relevant tissues
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838].


              **Conclusion:** This manuscript highlights the potential of
              PhenoPLIER to shift the interpretation of genetic studies from
              single genes to gene modules, thereby improving robustness in
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations and facilitating a
              better understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic
              modalities. By prioritizing alternative and potentially more
              promising candidate targets, PhenoPLIER offers enhanced
              mechanistic insights derived from statistical associations, paving
              the way for novel functional genomics applications in drug
              repurposing and precision medicine [@pmid:31036433].

              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and

              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the

              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;

              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

              ("PhenoPLIER" in output.split(".")[0])

              ---

              **Context:** Genetic studies often focus on individual genes, yet
              complex traits frequently involve interactions among multiple
              genes. To address this, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an "omnigenic"
              approach that considers groups of functionally-related genes. 


              **Content:** PhenoPLIER integrates different data types into a
              shared representation for joint analysis, enabling the inference
              of how gene modules influence complex traits and predicting
              pharmacological effects on gene activity. It maps gene-trait
              associations and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a
              common latent space using thousands of gene-trait associations
              from TWAS (PhenomeXcan) and transcriptional profiles of drugs from
              LINCS L1000, all integrated into a low-dimensional space learned
              from public gene expression data. When applied to various diseases
              and traits, PhenoPLIER reveals significant associations between
              diseases and gene modules expressed in relevant cell types. It
              also identifies modules associated with cell types under specific
              stimuli or disease states, and replicates significant module-trait
              associations in an independent cohort (eMERGE). A CRISPR screen
              shows that modules better predict drug-disease links than
              individual genes by capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological
              mechanisms.


              **Conclusion:** PhenoPLIER's module-based method provides a more
              robust and interpretable approach to genetic associations compared
              to single-gene methods. By incorporating groups of genes acting
              together in specific cell types, it can prioritize alternative
              candidate targets, even when known single gene associations are
              not detected. This shift in interpretation has the potential to
              extract mechanistic insights from statistical associations,
              ultimately enhancing our understanding of complex diseases and
              their therapeutic modalities.


              (References: [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225;
              @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049; @doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
              @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838;
              @doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72])
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;

              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

          - >-
            Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach that provides a
            gene module perspective to genetic studies. The flexibility of our
            method allows integrating different data modalities into the same
            representation for a joint analysis. We show that this module
            perspective can infer how groups of functionally-related genes
            influence complex traits, detect shared and distinct transcriptomic
            properties among traits, and predict how pharmacological
            perturbations affect genes' activity to exert their effects.
            PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and drug-induced
            transcriptional responses into a common latent representation. For
            this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait associations (using TWAS
            from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional
            profiles of drugs (from LINCS L1000
            [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space
            learned from public gene expression data on tens of thousands of
            RNA-seq samples (recount2 [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003;
            @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use a latent representation defined by a
            matrix factorization approach [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1;
            @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003] that extracts gene modules with
            certain sparsity constraints and preferences for those that align
            with prior knowledge (pathways). When mapping gene-trait
            associations to this reduced expression space, we observe that
            diseases are significantly associated with gene modules expressed in
            relevant cell types: such as hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal
            endothelial cells with keratometry measurements, hematological
            assays on specific blood cell types, plasma lipids with adipose
            tissue, and neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell
            types. Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large
            and heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
            associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states.
            We observe that significant module-trait associations in PhenomeXcan
            (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic Medical Records
            and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
            @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our replication cohort).
            Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to analyze lipid regulation
            in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust trait associations with
            modules than with individual genes, even when single genes known to
            be involved in lipid metabolism did not reach genome-wide
            significance. Compared to a single-gene approach, our module-based
            method also better predicts FDA-approved drug-disease links by
            capturing tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms linked with
            the mechanism of action of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular
            traits via a known immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease
            prediction suggests that modules may provide a better means to
            examine drug-disease relationships than individual genes. Finally,
            exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
            associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
            involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
            neuropsychiatric disorders. In summary, instead of considering
            single genes associated with different complex traits, PhenoPLIER
            incorporates groups of genes that act together to carry out
            different functions in specific cell types. This approach improves
            robustness in detecting and interpreting genetic associations, and
            here we show how it can prioritize alternative and potentially more
            promising candidate targets even when known single gene associations
            are not detected. The approach represents a conceptual shift in the
            interpretation of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract
            mechanistic insight from statistical associations to enhance the
            understanding of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              len(output.strip().split("\n")) == 1

              ---

              In this paper, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic method that
              offers a gene module viewpoint for genetic studies. Our approach
              accommodates various data modalities into a unified
              representation, facilitating joint analysis. We demonstrate that
              the module perspective can elucidate how groups of
              functionally-related genes impact complex traits, reveal shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              the effects of pharmacological perturbations on gene activity.


              PhenoPLIER integrates thousands of gene-trait associations (via
              TWAS from PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and drug
              transcriptional profiles (from LINCS L1000
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a low-dimensional space,
              learned from extensive public gene expression data on tens of
              thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We
              employ a latent representation based on matrix factorization
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those aligning with prior knowledge (e.g.,
              pathways).


              We observe significant associations between diseases and gene
              modules expressed in relevant cell types, such as hypothyroidism
              with T cells, keratometry measurements with corneal endothelial
              cells, hematological assays on specific blood cell types, adipose
              tissue with plasma lipids, and neuropsychiatric disorders with
              various brain cell types. Moreover, PhenoPLIER can identify
              modules associated with cell types under specific stimuli or
              disease states.


              Our findings indicate that significant module-trait associations
              in the discovery cohort (PhenomeXcan [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225]) replicate in the replication
              cohort (Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network
              phase III). A CRISPR screen for lipid regulation in HepG2 cells
              reveals more robust trait associations with modules than with
              individual genes, even when single genes involved in lipid
              metabolism do not reach genome-wide significance.


              Our module-based method outperforms single-gene approaches in
              predicting FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing
              tissue-specific pathophysiological mechanisms related to drug
              mechanisms of action (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via
              a known immune mechanism). This enhanced drug-disease prediction
              suggests that modules may serve as a better tool for examining
              drug-disease relationships than individual genes.


              Exploring the phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters
              associated with relevant tissues, including a complex branch
              involving lipids with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders. By considering groups of genes acting
              together in specific cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances robustness in
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations. Our approach also
              highlights alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets when known single gene associations are not detected,
              offering a paradigm shift for interpreting genetic studies and
              potential insights into complex disease mechanisms and therapeutic
              modalities.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the
              following paragraph from the Introduction section.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and
              interpreting genetic associations, and here we show how it can
              prioritize alternative and potentially more promising candidate
              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.

            text: >-
              Python code returned false

              ("PhenoPLIER" in output.split(".")[0])

              ---

              **Context:** Genetic studies have traditionally focused on
              individual genes, often overlooking the complexity of biological
              systems. However, recent advances in functional genomics and gene
              co-expression provide a new perspective for understanding genetic
              associations with complex traits and diseases. 


              **Content:** In this study, we introduce PhenoPLIER, an
              'omnigenic' approach that offers a gene module viewpoint to
              genetic studies. By flexibly integrating various data modalities
              into a joint analysis, PhenoPLIER can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes collectively influence complex traits,
              identify shared and distinct transcriptomic properties among
              traits, and predict the impact of pharmacological perturbations on
              gene activity. We achieve this by mapping gene-trait associations
              and drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation, learned from thousands of gene-trait associations
              and transcriptional profiles of drugs integrated into a
              low-dimensional space. Our method aligns gene modules with prior
              knowledge such as pathways and can identify modules associated
              with cell types under specific stimuli or disease states. We
              validate our approach using large and heterogeneous RNA-seq
              datasets, observing significant module-trait associations in both
              discovery and replication cohorts. Furthermore, we demonstrate
              that PhenoPLIER provides a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs.


              **Conclusion:** By incorporating groups of genes acting together
              in specific cell types, PhenoPLIER enhances robustness in
              detecting and interpreting genetic associations. This novel
              approach offers an opportunity to extract mechanistic insights
              from statistical associations, thereby advancing our understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities. In the era
              of precision medicine, this shift in the interpretation of genetic
              studies has the potential to uncover alternative and potentially
              more promising candidate targets for drug development and
              repurposing, especially when known single gene associations are
              not detected.
            prompt: >
              You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining
              the text of a manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations
              through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and
              drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional
              genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug
              repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise
              the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance
              clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The
              revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a
              Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure
              begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context),
              progresses through what is known from the literature (Content),
              and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap your
              manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1)
              preserve the original information as much as possible, with
              minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to
              scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the
              original text. These references are crucial for academic integrity
              and may appear in formats like "[@pmid:33931583;
              @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the
              revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following
              the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.


              Input paragraph: Here we propose PhenoPLIER, an omnigenic approach
              that provides a gene module perspective to genetic studies. The
              flexibility of our method allows integrating different data
              modalities into the same representation for a joint analysis. We
              show that this module perspective can infer how groups of
              functionally-related genes influence complex traits, detect shared
              and distinct transcriptomic properties among traits, and predict
              how pharmacological perturbations affect genes' activity to exert
              their effects. PhenoPLIER maps gene-trait associations and
              drug-induced transcriptional responses into a common latent
              representation. For this, we integrate thousands of gene-trait
              associations (using TWAS from PhenomeXcan
              [@doi:10.1126/sciadv.aba2083]) and transcriptional profiles of
              drugs (from LINCS L1000 [@doi:10.1016/j.cell.2017.10.049]) into a
              low-dimensional space learned from public gene expression data on
              tens of thousands of RNA-seq samples (recount2
              [@doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003; @doi:10.1038/nbt.3838]). We use
              a latent representation defined by a matrix factorization approach
              [@doi:10.1038/s41592-019-0456-1; @doi:10.1016/j.cels.2019.04.003]
              that extracts gene modules with certain sparsity constraints and
              preferences for those that align with prior knowledge (pathways).
              When mapping gene-trait associations to this reduced expression
              space, we observe that diseases are significantly associated with
              gene modules expressed in relevant cell types: such as
              hypothyroidism with T cells, corneal endothelial cells with
              keratometry measurements, hematological assays on specific blood
              cell types, plasma lipids with adipose tissue, and
              neuropsychiatric disorders with different brain cell types.
              Moreover, since PhenoPLIER can use models derived from large and
              heterogeneous RNA-seq datasets, we can also identify modules
              associated with cell types under specific stimuli or disease
              states. We observe that significant module-trait associations in
              PhenomeXcan (our discovery cohort) replicated in the Electronic
              Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) network phase III
              [@doi:10.1038/gim.2013.72; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225] (our
              replication cohort). Furthermore, we perform a CRISPR screen to
              analyze lipid regulation in HepG2 cells. We observe more robust
              trait associations with modules than with individual genes, even
              when single genes known to be involved in lipid metabolism did not
              reach genome-wide significance. Compared to a single-gene
              approach, our module-based method also better predicts
              FDA-approved drug-disease links by capturing tissue-specific
              pathophysiological mechanisms linked with the mechanism of action
              of drugs (e.g., niacin with cardiovascular traits via a known
              immune mechanism). This improved drug-disease prediction suggests
              that modules may provide a better means to examine drug-disease
              relationships than individual genes. Finally, exploring the
              phenotype-module space reveals stable trait clusters associated
              with relevant tissues, including a complex branch involving lipids
              with cardiovascular, autoimmune, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
              In summary, instead of considering single genes associated with
              different complex traits, PhenoPLIER incorporates groups of genes
              that act together to carry out different functions in specific
              cell types. This approach improves robustness in detecting and

              targets even when known single gene associations are not detected.
              The approach represents a conceptual shift in the interpretation
              of genetic studies. It has the potential to extract mechanistic
              insight from statistical associations to enhance the understanding
              of complex diseases and their therapeutic modalities.
